You are free to believe what you like. However there is a burden of rationality inherent in conversation particularly public ones. Advancing arguments of a god should require that you engage with the following:

1. Posit a set of axioms that exclude sought proof.
2. Define god. 
3. Define existence. 
4. Show objective evidence that a god meets that criteria.
5. Show that the result is significant! 

IMO.  Morality, just like god is likely a construct. It is an very important one, but a construct none the less. Arguments that rely on the most good, or the absoluteness of good are flawed. Humans certainly do not seem to be divine or special in any sense. It seems likely that we are simply cleverer animals. The initial formation of the universe is outside the boundaries of concrete knowledge. However the formation of the universe while including randomness, is not random.

Ms. Troll, I have never read any ISER report, seen a video, nor listened to any ISER representative say cutting Alaska's state budget will result in massive job losses.  I have heard, seen and read where they said, cutting the PFD is the absolutely worst thing government can do to solve this crisis.  I have heard them say that cutting government jobs is not the answer, either.  We have $9+/- billion in the Earnings Reserve (ER), up from $6.91 billion in 2015 (even with low oil prices), which the legislature can access with a simple 2/3 vote.  As ISER has said, with managed budget reductions over 3-5 years, and use of the ER to fill the $2-3 billion gaps during that process, Alaska will be in the black again.  Since the International Energy Agency is forecasting $80/bbl oil by 2021, the crisis is averted.  Not only that, we won't send another 12-15,000 Alaskans below the poverty level, nor will we severely weaken government.

"Based on the authors examples of Trump and vaccines, the author is talking about sympathy and compassion, both of which require of us to take sides."

That's incorrect. There's nothing about either sympathy or compassion that requires taking a side. 

The taking of sides is a strategic act, typically informed by both cognitive and emotional factors. Once a side is chosen, it tends to interfere with normal feelings of empathy and compassion. For example, when a player on the opposing team is injured, you're less likely to feel empathy for him than you would if it was a player on the team you support.

At least from a Buddhist's point of view, compassion can take no side. It's not an emotion. It's a state of being that's given freely to every living thing, without moralizing or politicizing the circumstances. Empathy on the other hand is an emotional connection between you and someone else, typically due to difficult circumstances the other is experiencing.

This misleading article refuses to die. Here is why this is bad advice:
1. Both defroster and heater take time to start working. If you start driving right away you will get foggy windows and no hands-free way to clear until the car warms up.
2. Cold oil does not lubricate as well, it is bad idea to apply load (start driving) the car until fluids had a chance to flow. Synthetic oil, plug-in oil pan heaters, heated garage and so on help with this. Unless you have one of these, wait a minute or so before you start to drive.
3. For cars sitting outside you should scrape ice from windows and clear the snow. There is no reason not to start the car while you are doing this.

The U.S. Constitution says "Each State shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof may direct, a Number of Electors . . ." 
The U.S. Supreme Court has repeatedly characterized the authority of the state legislatures over the manner of awarding their electoral votes as "plenary" and "exclusive."

The normal and intended way of changing the method of electing the President has been by changes in state law. 

Since its origination in 2006, the National Popular Vote bill has been introduced in legislatures in all 50 states and DC. 

More than 3,080 state legislators (in 50 states) have sponsored and/or cast recorded votes in favor of the bill. 

The bill has been debated in legislative chambers in 35 states.

It has passed 35 state legislative chambers in 23 rural, small, medium, large, Democratic, Republican and purple states with 261 electoral votes

I agree that it has to be more than a simple majority of votes cast, but I think the voting threshold should be even higher than you suggest (maybe 60% by population)?  It is so fundamental a change,  so expensive and something that is almost impossible to undo.  The experience of independence could be great, but could turn out to be awful. There is no guarantee that Catalan will be let into the EU, if they want that, or be allowed access to the Schengen  zone.  They may have to negotiate trade treaties with the rest of the world from a position of weakness.  These things could all give a serious case of regret to the populace.  Given that downside risk, I think you need a solid super-majority to show that people truly want it before it can happen, because there just seems to be practically no going back.  The spurned rump of Spain is going to be in no mood, for likely decades, if ever, to let a remorseful separatist Catalan back in if things don't work out for them.

It is too bad the understanding of most people in regards to energy generation, distribution, and use remains in the last century with little understanding of where things can and need to go.
Distributed generation and storage will evolve to much more reliable and inexpensive systems that we have been used to.  The concept of storage should not just be thought of as just batteries, for instance.  We have had grid storage in nuclear systems that run best at relatively constant output.  Pumped water storage was economical then as it is now. Thermal mass and phase change storage allows electric use at none peak times with making ice at night. Other forms of storage can be seen in phase change crystals in drywall. We will likely see a lot of grid stage as hydrogen which may be converted to things like ethanol for more convenient use in transportation.
HVDC lines are planned for moving energy from one part of the country to another.

The quote:  The minister of this sacrament is the priest, to whom it belongs to baptize, by reason of his office. What strikes me as most significant is that water drawn from the "high-level aquifer" is already brackish and approaching the point of not being drinkable.  That most likely indicates that the Ghyben-Herzberg freshwater lens under Lanai is relatively small and thin -- probably an ongoing natural condition (since Lanai sits somewhat in Maui's "rain shadow") and partly due to historic long-term depletion for agriculture.

It's an obvious fact of nature that one can't continue drawing more fresh water from this lens than it receives from natural "recharging" processes, without depleting it.  Excess withdrawal causes the "mixing zone" of brackish water to rise upward, and eventually freshwater wells start turning brackish.  

That the high-level aquifer water is brackish is great cause for concern -- and fiddling with the definition of "potable" so it can continue to be used for golf course irrigation is turning a blind eye to the problem and will only make it worse and more intractable.

Current Ontario electricity rates range from about 14.7 cents/kWh off-peak to 21.7 cents/kWh on-peak, so the prices you quote are actually $8.82 to $13.02 for a full 60kWh charge, maybe a couple dollars more when you factor in efficiency losses in charging.

Remember you pay for delivery, regulatory fees and taxes in addition to the straight-up electricity rate.

Still a cheaper energy source than a comparable gas powered car, particularly for high-performance vehicles, but it will take a lot of driving to make up for the higher up-front cost.  A Chevy Bolt, for example, will set you back almost $20,000 more than a similar sized and equipped Chevy Sonic (before subsidies), so even if all charging is done off-peak you're still looking at 275,000km+ before the cheaper fuel cost offsets the higher upfront cost.

The economics of electrics make a lot more sense when comparing a Tesla Model S vs. a BMW 7-series or some such, but most of us can't afford either a Model S or a 7-series.

Fair enough -- I shouldn't have called your accusation "dishonest," and I apologize for that. I still believe that accusation is ill-founded, but again, agree to disagree. I don't expect to change your mind, but I hope that I might show others that it's possible to defend a point without resorting to sarcasm and personal jabs. 

In fact, I do think it's possible to support both the NRA and aspects of gun control -- Wayne LaPierre himself supports enhancing our ability to restrict gun sales to the mentally ill. And I do think it's possible to be pro-life and support aspects of Planned Parenthood -- Planned Parenthood does much more than perform abortions, and of course it's possible to support their non-abortion aspects while maintaining pro-life principles. 

My point is that portraying these issues and organizations as black-and-white does the debate a disservice. Sure, navigating these contradictions can get a little messy, but we shouldn't reject somebody for attempting to do so.

I can't imagine that there would be a valid Constitutional claim against the business for enforcing a dress code, save for if the dress code itself was per-se discriminatory. If, and it's a big if, the dress code was put in place because the intent of the dress code was to keep a specific class or demographic group, who is protected under the 14th Amendment, out of the establishment, then that's a different story. Either way, if the APD used the language, as the article purports, and it was the officers' intent to remove him based on his ethnic, religious, etc... status, then it could be an interesting case. If the proprietor actually did ask the officers to remove him, and based their rationale on his dress code alone, then they were likely performing a trespass removal, under the color of law, and aren't liable for those actions. The fact that the establishment denies asking for assistance in removing an 'unwanted patron,' doesn't put the APD in a good spot.

Its very important to remember when using basal metabolic rate calculators online that they are not accurate.  Fat requires almost no calories for the body to maintain and has a poor blood supply.  Muscle on the other hand is the opposite.  When you punch in "sex/height/weight" the calculator has no idea if you are 300lbs of fat or muscle.  The article said the 300 lb man had a BMR of 800 calories less than a normal man of his size.  The only way this massive deficit is possible is if they are comparing him to a bodybuilder.  Its very rare for a 300 lb man to have a normal body fat composition.

There have been a few elections in Canadian history where the party with the most seats trailed in the popular vote. 

British Columbia provincial election, 1996: The NDP is re-elected with 39 seats, 6 more than the Liberals. However, the Liberals received about 37,000 more votes than the NDP.

Quebec provincial election 1998: The PQ is re-elected, winning 76 seats to 48 for the Liberals. This is despite the fact that the Liberals outpoll the PQ by over 27,000 votes province-wide.

New Brunswick provincial election, 2006: Shawn Graham's Liberals win 29 seats to the PC's 26 seats. However, the PCs carry the popular vote by a margin of more than 1300.

Federal election, 2000. About 152,000 more Quebecois vote for Liberal candidates to represent them in Ottawa than those who vote for the Bloc Quebecois. Nevertheless, the BQ squeaks past the Liberals in terms of seats 38 to 36.

There are numerous similar cases from past elections of other countries, including those that use FPTP.

This is fine exegesis of the "render unto Caesar" incident in Matthew. However, Mark and Luke also report the exchange. I think a composite of all three brings us closer to knowing exactly what transpired. In that light, you may consider minor alterations in your view.

"If Jesus said, "Pay," he implicitly acknowledged the legitimacy of the Roman occupation, pagan rule over God's people."

Many Church scholars since Eusebius say the question was designed to trap Jesus however he answered. This is wrong. His enemies knew Jesus would never endorse Caesar's tax, nor any tax collected by force or coercion. Luke's account is clear: the only answer his enemies expected was, "No, don't pay!" Then they could hand him over to Pilate for execution as a "tax denier." (IRS term) Indubitably, "repay to Caesar what belongs to Caesar," means give him nothing that isn't his. And what belongs to God also leaves nothing for Caesar.  No wonder Rome's chief tax collector for Judea murdered him. (seeLK 23)

The premise of the article is essentially artificial because it's impossible to discuss immigration without discussing the social, political and economic circumstances that have impacted immigration policy. In the West, immigration restrictions proliferated in tandem with industrialization, the rise of labour rights and, most importantly, the emergence of universal suffrage and the associated transformation of the role of the state. Is it surprising that people will vote to protect themselves against unrestricted competition, particularly when they're experiencing hardship or are anxious about the future? The very idea of citizenship focuses on the notion that membership has its privileges, one of which is the understanding that a primary purpose of the state is to promote and protect the interests of those living within its boundaries. If ever there was an article that should have been vetted by a farmer, this is it. While interesting and well-written in general, a farmer see the holes, such as. "Josh Proctor tended the rows of tiny shoots poking from his cornfield at all hours of the early summer night, picking his way through the dark to check on irrigation channels easily choked by trash and weeds in a season of unusually abundant rainfall." One doesn't irrigate tiny shoots of corn with gravity flow irrigation. The corn has to be tall enough to not drown. Then there is this, which even a city person should have thought through: "He had spent the winter using borrowed tractors to plant corn, alfalfa and wheat on about 300 acres." You don't plant crops in the winter in Colorado. I do thank the writer for trying to get the word out. Just a little more attention to detail would have helped.

Work Farce:

Your point regarding the need to be aware of the costs and consequences of the First World War is valid. However, you generalize to the point of absurdity when you make a statement such as "that Germany was immediately determined to wage a war of revenge (WWII)." 

What is ignored is twenty years of German domestic politics and developments in international affairs, all of which could have produced a much different outcome. Decisions made in Berlin, London, Paris, Moscow, Washington, Rome, and all the other major seats of power - including Geneva, home of the League of Nations , and New York, centre of world finances - all had a bearing on how the world shaped itself after the treaties were concluded in 1919.

At first glance, history appears to be written by the victors. Look deeper and you will find that there is a chorus of voices, both nuanced and bombastic, on such subjects. Expect more as we approach the centenary.

I'm a trained historian, but only one voice.

I've owned a Chevy Volt for a bit more than four years now and while I've not been entirely satisfied with my Volt, it's almost a certainty that I'll never buy another pure-ICE (gasoline) vehicle again. In my region, where we burn almost no coal to generate electricity, the Volt is far better for the environment than a gasoline car. The Volt is a joy to drive: it's quiet and quick and handles very well. And the Volt's range-extending EV design means there's no "range anxiety" whatsoever; we've taken it on very long holiday trips.

I suggest that you read up a bit on the history. There is a mnemonic about the fates of Henry VI's wives: "Divorced, beheaded, died. Divorced, beheaded, survived." Henry VIII beheaded two of his wives, Anne Boleyn (on trumped-up charges) and Catherine Howard (on quite legitimate charges -- adultery by the queen was treason under the statute). Of the others, two were divorced (one for non-consumation), one died in childbirth and the sixth outlived him.

Henry actually had solid grounds for an annulment. His father, Henry VII, arranged a marriage between his eldest son, Arthur, and Catherine of Aragon. A few months afterwards, Arthur died. The king wanted to keep the Catherine's dowry (over a million in today's currency, which would have had to be repaid out of the Privy Purse). So he decided to marry his second son, Henry, to Catherine. There was a problem: Under Church marriage law, one cannot marry one's deceased spouse's sibling.

Your statement that the Tongass has 17 million acres may be true, but is not accurate if intended to imply that much land is available for timber harvest.  The 17 million acres includes all the mountaintops and glaciers in the Tongass.  The potentially suitable lowest land is 2+ million acres.  If you eliminate the acreage  of forest land  located within land use designations (LUDs) that do not allow timber harvest, etc, you get to an existing timber base- including second growth, I believe- of approximately 600,000 acres.  A far cry from 17,000,000 acres comprising the total forest.

Source:  Look up Diefenbaker's National Oil Policy, 1961, which created a protected market for Alberta's oil industry.  All provinces from Ontario west paid above market-prices for Alberta oil for about 10 years to support development of Alberta's young oil sector.  

Because Quebec and Atlantic Canada have easy access to oil by sea, they were exempted from the NOP and continued to buy oil in international markets.  The expense of an oil pipeline east was considered foolish.

The spike in global oil prices in the early 70s then gave rise to the NEP, when government wanted to pay Alberta less than market prices to help even out the price shock.  But as we know, Alberta was suddenly all about free markets, and any attempt at a made-in-Canada oil policy pretty much ended with the epic NEP dust-up.

You know, to steal something one must deprive the rightful owner of its use.  Writing from the vantage point of someone from different cultures/sub-cultures or expressing views with respect to different cultures does not deprive members of such cultures/sub-cultures from expressing their own views.  In any event, the sad reality is that such "appropriation" has also been beneficial to the cultures appropriated.  Non-aboriginal writers writing with an aboriginal voice have made many aware of the systemic abuses against aboriginals.  Just as white musicians--by "appropriating" the music of  the black community--brought attention to that community and were instrumental in ensuring that black musicians were recognized and honoured.  One could argue that it is lamentable that such "appropriation" was required in the first place, but the unfortunate reality is that it was, and that it did have a positive effect on recognition of the cultures appropriated.

I was Cinematographer on this movie and have sent an email to Ms. Spitz requesting a correction today. Will update and let you know how it went.

This was my very first experience working on a film and am honored to have worked with such a great cast and crew! Long hot days in the high desert, parkour leaping across boulders, balancing on cliff edges, and braving tarantula-killer wasps and rattle snakes, and even (on the last day of shooting) torrential rains. But it was all worth it all to get the perfect shot!

I served two primary roles including PRODUCTION ASSISTANT and ASSISTANT DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY (credited as "Cinematographer" on IMDB). I also contributed to still photography, location scouting, script/dialogue development, and even got to do some of the special effects (blood splatter).

All in all, it was an amazing experience under a talented, demanding-but-fair visionary new director named Isaac Medeiros.

RG, thanks for the article on the "Wine Trail" with the six local wineries flourishing in their "unique microclimate  in the coastal foothills."

However, all are actually   to the west of JC, and in fact are west of Territorial Highway and the Long Tom River.  Your directions of driving north on 99 to JC are OK for those who live in Eugene, but not for all of us in Central and Western Lane County. We simply drive north  on historic Territorial Highway, which Eugeneans and Springfielders can also do after driving west to Veneta, to "enjoy the country drive with beautiful scenery all around."

While  "Prairie Mountain"  is a special area, you'll find a scattering of  fine wineries  and a few restaurants all  along Territorial by  the Coast Range  foothills south  to Lorane.

"After the federal government introduced Bill C-56 in late June that would restrict how long inmates can be placed in solitary confinement..."

That statement is incorrect. Bill C-56 does NOT restrict how long a prisoner may be kept in solitary confinement. This includes younger offenders and prisoners with mental health issues. Bill C-56 simply requires that the warden who sends the prisoner to solitary confinement shall file a report on the matter after 15 days. After that, there's no limit to the amount of time a prisoner may be kept in isolation. 

You can see the facts for yourself at the following link:

http://www.parl.ca/DocumentViewer/en/42-1/bill/C-56/first-reading

In her opening statement, Chair Yellen said “Core inflation…has been little changed in recent months at about 1-3/4 percent.” PCEPILFE, the US Fed’s preferred measure, was at 1.7% in January, unchanged from December. However, if one looks at a more current measure of inflation, the annualized three-month rate of change, it almost doubled from 1.1% in December to 1.9% in January. So the core inflation data really also support the case for an interest rate increase. The PCEPILFE inflation rate was lower or equal to the corresponding rate for CPIX, the Bank of Canada’s operational guide until this year, from June 2014 to September 2016. Since then it has been at the same level or higher. The US Fed’s preferred core inflation measure is now showing a higher inflation rate than that of any other preferred inflation measure of a G-7 central bank.

There are 17-18 K employees in the Executive Branch.   About 15K are union, including all the State's supervisors and confidentials, and even including the State's labor negotiators.   So, 2-3K exempt, partially-exempt and elected/appointed who are non-union.   Last I looked there were a couple hundred division directors or similar positions, a C step director is about $110K.   There are several hundred non-union AAGs in State Ranges 20 - 24 or so, $80 - $100K, and there are also lots of clerks and technicians who for one reason or another are non-union, mostly because of who they report to.

Richard Phillips wrote, in response to my suggestion that a state income tax would have the advantage of getting revenue from those who live out of state but work here, "The courts already ruled against taxing out of state residents."

This is completely wrong. There are many people who live in one state and work in another. If both states have an income tax, then taxes are paid to both states—to simplify somewhat, the state where the individual works but doesn't live is entitled to tax on only the income earned in that state, while the state of residence is entitled to tax on all income earned, but with a credit for income tax paid to other states.

Yes, it can get complicated, but it's a pretty common situation (just look at how many people live in New Jersey or Connecticut but work in New York City, for one example). There is no basis to a claim that out of state residents wouldn't be subject to income taxes here.

The criteria for doctors to force someone to be confined to a psychiatric hospital against his or her will is determined by state law.  In almost all states that means the individual is deemed to be an imminent threat to self or others on the basis of a mental illness.  Imminent is held to mean, and is reflected in the standard of care,  that the mentally ill person has very recently made such an attempt or communicated their plan to soon carry out that intent.  Yes, this very sick individual committed  a heinous act consequent to a mental illness, but there is no report that he communicated his intent to anyone and the hospitalization in question occurred weeks earlier I do believe.  The treating doctor and hospital are required, by law, to release that person once the imminent threat is deemed to no longer exist.  The key word is "imminent.".  The law determines the criteria, not the doctor.

200 vacancies in the PD. Training normally has 30 vacancies which they use to fill attrition rates , but with 200 vacancies they are far behind their allocated strength. What this translates into, no recruit classes or they are very small under 20 and they are only filling priority  uniform patrol slots. After graduation recruit is assigned to FTO-16 weeks of OJT with a rater. When they complete this training, they are assigned to 4th Platoon, Waikiki, and work foot beats alone or in pairs but because of the shortage, when they complete FTO, they go out into the patrol districts to fill motor beats(white car drivers). CRU Units(plainclothes patrol officer usually assigned to target property crimes in the patrol district) are also impacted meaning a commander will put those resources back into uniform to fill patrol beats. It is probably getting worse because lots of recruits are quitting while in recruit school, not cut out for the regimentation, new generation entering work force.

That's a lot of guns, but your statistics aren't applied properly and are misleading. Actual gun ownership is confined to about 30% of citizens, down from over 50% in 1973, when percent of gun ownership peaked. If US population is 325 million and 30% own guns, then 97.5 million people own an average 3.38 guns apiece. Incorrect. The mill rate adjustment is not transparent. Only the CPAs at city hall know the actual costs and revenue coverage required. This is an entirely sneaking way of increasing the cost burden on the taxpayer beyond requirements by picking up an extra dollar to spend. The surplus goes into a holding account to be reallocated for the next fiscal pet project.

Should it be named for Ken  Kesey or Timothy Leary?  

Dr. Timothy Leary, a lecturer in psychology at Harvard University, was the most prominent pro-LSD researcher. Leary claimed that using LSD with the right dosage, set (what one brings to the experience), and setting, preferably with the guidance of professionals, could alter behavior in dramatic and beneficial ways.

At Stanford in 1959, Kesey volunteered to take part in a CIA-financed study named Project MKULTRA.  The project studied the effects on the patients of psychoactive drugs, particularly LSD, psilocybin, mescaline, cocaine, AMT, and DMT.  Kesey wrote many detailed accounts of his experiences with these drugs, both during the Project MKULTRA study and in the years of private experimentation that followed. Kesey's role as a medical guinea pig inspired him to write One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest in 1962. 

In the summer of 1964, Kesey's Merry Pranksters customized a bus and set out on a tour to propagate LSD use.

In the area of Alaska where I live, our Borough (county) has similar regulations with fines. We have a Compliance Officer and he moves very quickly, on reports of junky yards, garbage and unsafe health conditions such as septic tanks and junk cars. 
First of all, no one here waits around for a yard to fill up with junk. The CO comes out photographs the violations and tickets the homeowner. If it is not corrected within ten days, they go to court and get a judgement with a court order. They can then go onto the property and removed whatever it is and dispose of it. A bill for that is added on to the fines which is then added onto the property tax bill. Eventually, if taxes are not paid in two years the property is seized and auctioned off. I may have skipped a legal step or two, but it does get taken care of. Part of it is nipping it in the "bud". Not sitting back and wat hing the pile get higher. 
Neighbors will offer to help but if turned away it goes to the CO. We pay taxes for it

"The difference between willingly risking one’s life and health in service of country and risking one’s life and health for the profits of tobacco companies is vast."

I do not know a single person who smokes for the express benefit of tobacco companies in the same way they serve in the military for the benefit of their country. Usually they smoke because they like to smoke. The RG's comparison is absurdly unhelpful.

I hate smoking, particularly when my neighbor does so on his porch for an hour at dawn, and his smoke drifts in my window as I try to cool my house. Even so, I prefer people have the right to make the decision to smoke for themselves once they are of reasonable age to know the consequences, which they certainly should by 18. However, they should not be able to force others to bear any part of the costs of that decision. Tobacco should be taxed at a rate to cover all health costs for its use. Those taxes should be held in a superfund which would reimburse health providers.

Things have changed a bit though.  Back in 1980 Pierre Trudeau didn't win a so much as a single one of the 63 seats in SK, AB and BC, but won 74 of the 75 seats in Quebec.  That was just over half of the seats the Liberals won for the country as a whole.

Today though there are 88 seats in SK, AB and BC combined vs. only 78 seats in Quebec.  The Atlantic Provinces, meanwhile, still have the same 32 seats that they had in 1980.

Ontario is still the big battleground, with 121 seats in the house.  The real question here is who is going to take the 60 or so suburban seats in Ontario.  Downtown Toronto will vote Liberal or NDP and rural Ontario will vote Conservatives, but there are a lot of seats up for grabs in between those two.

Under Oregon law, since very early times, (I can't tell you the exact date, but it was early) counties have been responsible for building and maintaining courthouses.  The State of Oregon pays the salaries of the judges and the staff.  This was a system of split costs.

Then Klamath County lost its courthouse in an earthquake a while back and the citizens were unwilling to rebuild a new state of the art courthouse at their expense.  Klamath County was poor and underpopulated making an expensive courthouse impossible.  So the legislature had to fund most if not all of the cost of the new courthouse.

This got folks in Salem thinking about the future of courthouses in Oregon and particularly funding for new construction.  It has been debated whether the state should assume full responsibility for the cost of new courthouses but the state cannot do so right now.  Without legislative approval for cost sharing, Lane County taxpayers will be liable for the entire $200 million courthouse cost

"97% Consensus Lie"

That is another one of many lies from you.  There is not enough space here to explain it in detail, but every attempted rebuttal of Cook (2013) has been based on egregious errors in math and logic by the alleged "debunkers."
1) They define consenusus incorrectly as the number of papers with quantitative evidence for AGW.  Nope.  Consensus means general agreement among experts that AGW is valid.  That is the way Cook defined it.
2) They incorrectly include papers that are irrelevant to the question in the denominator, making the fraction arbitrarily small.  Cook correctly culled out "no position" papers.
3) They ignore a theorem that the sum of probabilities of all outcomes in sample space must = 1.  Cook satisfied that theorem.

Besides, you have the fact that not a single science organization or society in the world disagrees with AGW, which affirms the seven published papers on this subject.

Workers must adapt to the new jobs of the future rather than expect job to be tailored to their needs. Unfortunately the jobs of the future have not yet been created so workers cannot train for them until they arrive.

Our government should commit to more retraining programs as well as support to selective economic sectors that are showing success in this turbulent environment.

Tax rates do not tell the whole story of tax bills in Maui.
For a vacation rental condo, (not an owner operated B&B), the tax rate is $9.37/$1000, for a property assessed at say $450,000 the tax bill comes to $4216. 

For a Maui resident homeowner, the tax rate is $2.86/$1000 after a $200,000 homeowner exemption is applied. For the same property assessed at $450,000 this comes to a tax bill of $715. Approximately 6 times greater for the vacation rental condo. 

For an owner operted B&B property, the tax rate is $4.56 and the homeowner living in the B&B loses his exmeption so on the same $450,000 value he pays $2052  instead of $715.

Thomas Condon, who is well recognized at the John Day center  for his discoveries, was from Eugene, and was the University of Oregon's  first great professor of the 19th Century.   Many of his fossils are on display at the UO Museum of Natural History.
The house in which he  and Cornelia lived, formerly at 11th and High, is now at 1272 Jackson.  Condon, who was both a missionary and a scientist was famous for blending science and religion.  In  an interesting sidelight  relevant to current issues, Condon  lost one of his early preacher positions because of his opposition to slavery.
Basically, he was a great guy.
If you are interested,  read Clark's "Odyssey of Thomas Condon." This and his daughter Ellen Condon McCornack's book are wonderful as they describe his discoveries in these beautiful fossil beds.

Where ASD puts 200 teachers' jobs on the line and threatens to cut the cord? It's not a threat - it's a legal obligation.

The teachers have a contract. That contract has a provision whereby notice has to be given by a certain date if the position is not funded. Funding is dependent on legislative appropriation, and the House and Senate are far apart on what amount of funding they are willing to provide.

What would be irresponsible would be to let the layoff notice date pass without comment, then find themselves on the hook for all the teachers they are contracted to pay but with no funds to pay them.

If education were forward funded, then districts would only have to send out layoff notices to those teachers who they were certain would not be retained, but that's not the environment we live in.

There is no doubt ancient Polynesians were great seafarers and were able to navigating from island to island using non-instrument navigation, but it is nonsense to say the first Polynesians to arrive here used such techniques to find the Hawaiian Islands.  To navigate successfully from point A to point B using non-instrument or Celestial navigation, you must know point B exists and you must know the positioning of the sun, moon, stars and planets along the route.  The first Polynesians to arrive in our islands had no idea they existed and would not have known the positioning of celestial bodies to guide them, so they could not have used non-instrument navigation to find Hawaii. The theory that they accidentally drifted here as castaways, supported by scientist like Thor Heyerdahl, is the one that makes sense.

Sigh.  Human Rights Tribunals don't 'convict.'

If you don't like a decision of a Tribunal, you can apply for judicial review. 

If you refuse to pay the money they order you pay the complainant, you might have your wages garnisheed or your office furniture sold.  

If you refuse a direct non-monetary order of any civil court or tribunal - after exhausting all avenues of judicial review and appeal -  yes you might be found guilty of contempt, and, who knows, it might lead to jail.  It's called the rule of law and it applies to any of the thousands of different types of tribunals and civil courts in Canada.

If there is a trial for contempt, it will be in a court, and will use the criminal standard of proof beyond a reasonable doubt.

The church presents celibacy as a charism, a gift, given to certain members of the believing community as a witness oriented to the kingdom of God in which women and men will neither marry nor be given in marriage. 
The Sacrament of Orders celebrates and confirms the call of certain members of the community to celebrate the sacraments of the church with and for their sisters and brothers.
There is no logical or necessary connection between the two.  A person gifted with the charism of celibacy may or may not be called to Orders; a person called to Orders may or may not also be entrusted with the charism of celibacy.
The discipline that links the two -- that requires celibacy as a condition for orders -- artificially shrinks the pool of candidates for orders, and it disfigures the charism of celibacy. "Mandatory celibacy" is an oxymoron, if celibacy is understood as a charism.
Enforcing celibacy on a widowed deacon is simply, incredibly stupid. The bishop ought to be ashamed.

I'm reminded of that landmark paper: _The Basic Laws of Human Stupidity_ by Carlo M. Cipolla, Former Professor of Economics at University UC Berkeley.

-First Law: Always and inevitably everyone underestimates the number of stupid individuals in circulation.
-Second Law: The probability that a certain person be stupid is independent of any other characteristic of that person.
-Third (and Golden) Law: A stupid person is a person who causes losses to another person or to a group of persons while himself deriving no gain and even possibly incurring losses.
-Fourth Law: Non-stupid people always underestimate the damaging power of stupid individuals. In particular non-stupid people constantly forget that at -all times and places and under any circumstances to deal and/or associate with stupid people always turns out to be a costly mistake.
-Fifth Law: A stupid person is the most dangerous type of person.
-Corollary to the 5th Law: A stupid person is more dangerous than a bandit.
